title: Brittany helps Ireland to third place in the Women’s Six Nations
story: KILLINCHY rugby star Brittany Hogan helped Ireland secure third place in the Womenrsquos Six Nations as they defeated Italy -.Hoganmade her first start for the national team as they comfortably overpowered the Italians, who never really looked like winning.It was a pivotal match to be introduced to a starting role in, as Hogan reflected on receiving the call from head coach Adam Griggs.ldquoI felt a couple of emotions when i was picked to start, I was extremely excited and nervous, she said.ldquoI was literally shaking. I was working on my university dissertation with a friend when my coach phoned me and told me the news. I really went through the motions.Griggs told Hogan that she would be starting in the No  role, not her usual second row position on the pitch.ldquoAdam said that he knew I had to adjust to playing the role but that he was confident that I was capable of doing that, she continued.ldquoDue to the lack of playing time because of Covid- the coach wanted to try me out in dferent field positions to see what Irsquoll suit best.ldquoI knew from my background all the roles the second row has to do. I had been doing some back row work in training but itrsquos a dferent set-up in defence. So I wanted to make sure I knew what I was doing and where I needed to be.The third place decider took place in Donnybrook, Dublin, after the fixture was relocated from Parma due to quarantining issues.ldquoItaly decided to come over to Dublin due to Covid-, which was great of them. That acted as a comfort as I was in similar surroundings when we played France, said Hogan.Ireland started the match strongly, with the game plan of keeping the ball tightly in control until the hour mark. The green and white outfit betted on having the superior stamina over their Italian counterparts which would ultimately help them see off the game comfortably.ldquoWe certainly kept them into the middle of the field throughout the first half, said Hogan.ldquoWe knew coming into the game that we had to be patient andwe wanted the result we needed to be in control until at least  minutes had went on the clock.ldquoWe knew our test fitness is better than Italyrsquos and we would have the legs to get over the line.Ireland faced an early scare when they lost their captain Ciara Grfin to a head injury assessment within the opening quarter of the game. Grfin was subsequently replaced with Hannah OrsquoConnor.ldquoWe had prepared foranyone got a yellow card whilst in training, so when Ciara went off the field we had an idea on how to manage, said Hogan.ldquoWe had Hannah come on the pitch and with her leadership she showed great composure and intelligence. I think we did really well considering we lost our captain.Ireland maintained in control and comfortably seen out the contest to secure third place in this yearrsquos Six Nations. After the final whistle blew Griggs briefly congratulated Hogan on her performance. The local rugby ace said she was lsquomostly happyrsquo with the sht she put in.ldquoIn the first  minutes I made a few silly errors, but i just had to bounce back from that and I was happy with my defensive work. Therersquos always areas to improve in order to contribute to the team.Ireland will get little time to rest on their laurels as they look ahead to the World Cup qualiers in which they will feature Italy, Scotland and the winners of the Rugby Europe Womenrsquos Championship..prettyPhoto

title: Budding snappers take part in exciting photography workshop
story: A NEW creative arts photography initiative spearheaded by Newry, Mourne and Down Council has been hailed a major success.People from across the local authorityrsquos seven district electoral took part in the project to help them with emotional anguish as a result of coronavirus lockdown restrictions.Bringing people together from dferent isolated cultural backgrounds in a shared, safe environment, the initiative was designed to promote understanding and acceptance and develop their photography skills.A total of  people from the seven DEArsquos participated in the creative arts photography programme was conducted virtually via Zoom and facilitated by award-winning professional photographers Raphael Mason and Philip Kelly.Over a four-week period between November last year and January, participants in each of the DEArsquos met weekly to discuss lighting, backgrounds and techniques to help them increase their knowledge and confidence in producing improved quality photographs and engage with each other in a social environment.Where permitted within Covid- regulations, a location shoot took place where participants met socially distanced and shared their experience of participating in the project and had the opportunity to take photographs on the day, with the results featuring in an exhibition of their work.Due to Covid regulations an exhibition of the photographs produced during the project was held virtually via Zoom to allow participants to view the work of other groups and to connect in a social setting.Feedback from the programme has been overwhelmingly positive with praise being lavished on the facilitators for their professionalism, knowledge and ability to inspire participants to continue their photography journey.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin described the creative photography event as an ldquoexciting programme which allowed people suffering from social or rural isolation to come together to meet like-minded iniduals and enhance their photography skills.ldquoDuring the pandemic, people have been increasingly walking outdoors for exercise and following this excellent course with participants now equipped with the necessary skills to take high quality images whilst out and about and provide them with a new hobby, she said.Cllr Devlin added: ldquoProjects such as this combat the physical and mental health problems associated with the pandemic by bringing participants from dferent communities and cultures to come together in a social setting and judging by the quality of photographs produced the initiative was a great success..prettyPhoto

title: Castlewellan drama group perform on radio
story: DRAMA group Castlewellan Studio Players is keeping amateur theatre alive during the pandemic by teaming up with FM Down Community Radio.It was founded in  by local speech and drama teacher Michelle Dorans, who was determined to fulfil a long held ambition to establish a local theatre group.However, last yearrsquos lockdown meant that its debut performance scheduled for May had to be postponed, along with several others in the pipeline.Michelle, who runs the Dorans Academy of Speech and Drama, school, explained that the love of acting was such that the newly founded group was determined to find a way to keep up interest and momentum.ldquoCastlewellan Studio Players have been determined to keep connected with the public, she said. ldquoDuring this second intense lockdown, its writing group have continued their weekly Zoom meetings and decidedthey couldnrsquot meet the public face to face, they would embrace the opportunity to hit the airwaves and perform via a medium that has kept the world connected through the greatest of crisis.After a chance meeting earlier this year between CSP member Harry Mitchell and local radio presenter Chris Scott, further contacts were made and CSP came up with an idea to try out some of their sketches on radio.Due to current restrictions the Players were unable to meet together and record under one roof, so they came up with the idea of recording themselves separately and then putting the material together via an editing suite to produce the finished product for broadcast.Chris, having listened to sample material produced by the Players, agreed to put it onto his radio show on FM Down Community Radio.ldquoI received a number of poems and sketch material in my inbox over a period of weeks, all original material written and performed by the Players. I was really impressed by their talent and enthusiasm, and I was keen to get it on air for them, he said.The first sketch, a comedy entitled, ACheap Day Out, written by Harry Mitchell and performed by Harry Mitchell, Michelle Dorans, Mark Lamms, Brigida Croskery and Anthony McFadden will be broadcast on the Chris Scott Show next Wednesday, May , at pm.There are plans to broadcast more of the Playersrsquo material on the Chris Scott Show commencing on May  with another comedy sketch series, The Amazing Adventures of Johnathan lsquoNo Middle Namersquo Jackson, written by Anthony McFadden.If you are outside the FM signal area, you can ask your smart speaker to play FM Down Community Radio. The show is repeated each Sunday from -pm and the highlights of each show are available on Soundcloud.For more information on Castlewellan Studio Players ndash contact the Facebook page CastlewellanStudioPlayers.prettyPhoto

title: Covid recovery opportunity to reverse ‘seriously flawed policies’
story: HEALTH campaigners are to provide politicians with ldquosubstantial evidence on the importance of local hospitals and the key role they play as they ramp up the campaign for the retention and enhancement of services at the Downe Hospital.This week, the Down Community Health Committee has called on Stormont health minister Robin Swann, his department, health and social care trusts and political decision makers to reflect upon the consequences of  years of centralisation of health services in a handful of so-called ldquogolden hospitals.The committeersquos chairman, Mr Eamonn McGrady, said that the rebuilding of post Covid health and social care services afforded ldquoa particular, unique opportunity for those charged with health and social care decision making to reverse the ldquoseriously flawed policies of the past.He said there exists an opportunity to restore what he described as a ldquobalanced and fair model of healthcare that would meet the needs of the entire community, deliver on the task of tackling health inequalities, be more economic, effective and efficient.ldquoThere is an excellent opportunity now for decision makers, rather than rushing ahead to implement flawed decisions, pursuing an old and failed agenda, to look afresh instead at what can be done with existing resources and with modest additional capital spend, to concentrate efforts now in rebuilding and expanding service provision in smaller hospitals, said Mr McGrady.ldquoLater this week, we will be writing directly to senior politicians, those who bear the ultimate responsibility for healthcare decision making, providing them with substantial evidence about the importance of smaller hospitals, the role they play in England and the Republic of Ireland and busting some of the myths that have influenced decision making in Northern Ireland for years.Veteran health campaigner, Mrs Ann Trainor, said it has been ldquoextraordinarily convenient for some to ignore the potential of smaller hospitals, the superior models of care involving their utilisation where and to focus instead on the easy option of centralisation, despite that policy of yesteryear leaving us facing into a pandemic short of hospital beds, intensive care beds, staff to operate them and even PPE for the staff to wear.Mrs Trainor said it was time to go right back to first principles.ldquoIt is the people who own the NHS and the people who fund it, which they do with a heart and a half and it is the people who use it, she remarked.ldquoWe are the custodians of the NHS from one generation to the next. This generation will not be the one that fails it.Last week, the health minister was asked to provide clarity on the future role of the Downe Hospital with the appeal by South Down MLA Colin McGrath coming after Mr Swann warned that the health service should not be used as a political football in the run-up to next Mayrsquos Assembly elections.He said attempts to rebuild and revitalise the health service in Northern Ireland must not be hijacked by politicians hoping to win votes and called on his Stormont colleagues to support transformation that will result in better patient outcomes.Outlining plans for the health service as the province edges out of lockdown, Mr Swann said it will see more services offered on a regional basis, meaning patients may have to travel further for hospital appointments and operations.The health minister said he believed that a campaign had already started for a long-term commitment to the Downe Hospital, suggesting that it is ldquothis sort of language that then unnerves staff.The health minister said there was ldquonothing more unnerving than social media campaigns for the people who are working in our health service at this minute in time about saving their hospital when their hospital is not under threat.Mr Swann said the health service did not have enough staff and needed more, insisting that ldquonobody is going to be done away with.The health minister added: ldquoWe donrsquot have a big enough footprint so we need every square foot that we have, but it may not be that everybody gets every service that they want delivered on their doorstep..prettyPhoto

title: Danny wins jockeys’ title
story: DOWNPATRICK native Danny McMenamin crowned a great season on Saturday at Sandown Park when he was presented with his trophy as thechampion conditional jockey, finishing well clear of his closest rivals.He becomes the latest Northern Ireland jockey to land the title and he was full of praise for Anthony Dobbin, who was responsible for him joining the stable of Nicky Richards, and to his coach, Richardsrsquo former stable jockey, Cork-born Brian Harding.With Downpatrickrsquos next meeting due on May , it would be niceDanny was offered some rides at the venue. Watering is already taking place at the track due to the long dry spell.There was success for another Downpatrick native on Tuesday of last week at Tipperary when Catriona MacNabbrsquos Inventor won the Thank You Frontline Workers Handicap.The horse was ridden by her husband, Billy Lee mdash the couple got married in Downpatrick during lockdown. Billyrsquos sister, Gillian Scott, was the successful trainer.The winner was picked up for just pound, at the sales last autumn.The passing of English amateur jockey Lorna Brooke has saddened all those that follow horse racing. Back in  Lorna rode at a Down Royal meeting..prettyPhoto

title: Destruction to 900 acres
story: THE blazing wildfire which ripped through the Mournes last weekend leaving a trail of environmental destruction in its wake was started deliberately.Police have launched an investigation into the inferno which they believe was started at a walkway at the Bloody Bridge area late last Thursday night before spreading rapidly due to tinder dry conditions and wind.Almost  acres of precious habitat were destroyed with the scars left in an area of outstanding natural beauty by one of the biggest gorse fires in living memory in Northern Ireland taking many years to heal.There has also been widespread praise mdash led by the First and Deputy First Ministers ndash for all those who worked in gruelling conditions as part of the cross-border multi-agency approach to bring the blaze under control within two and a half days.Huge flames fanned by winds and dficult terrain presented firefiighters with signicant challenges as they worked around the clock to save as much of a landscape teaming with le as they could during what was a complex operation.Some had to travel up to an hour on foot to reach the blaze carrying their equipment with small pumps used to drain water from rivers and other small pockets of water that they could find. Firefighters also used back pack sprayers but the majority had to use shovels and beaters to tackle the fire in harsh conditions.The environmental impact of the blaze mdash which could be seen up to  miles away mdash is immeasurable as work now starts to draw up plans up for a major conservation restoration programme following the loss of precious wildle habitats.National Trust officials who have surveyed the scale of the damage say they have never seen anything like it before, describing parts of the mountain range as resembling a ldquolunar landscape, estimating that the once rich habitat could take up to five years to recover.Over  firefighters were involved in the battle to contain the blaze with dramatic images captured last Friday night illustrating the scale of the task they faced and making the front pages of major UK newspapers.The following morning, the Fire and Rescue Service declared a major incident as the battle to contain the fire which was destroying everything in its path was ramped up, with firefighters from across Northern Ireland helping out.Firefighters have also been praised for preventing the wildfire from reaching Donard Forest on the slopes of the Mournes by using a blanket of foam as part of a fire break.When the flames were finally put out late on Sunday afternoon, exhausted firefighters who had to carry their equipment to remote locations began to pack up toto their bases after spending many hours working in challenging conditions.One of the driest Aprils on record increased the risk and challenges for those tackling the huge gorse fire with a blanket of smoke engulfing the spectacular mountain range, with the emergency response involving Coastguard helicopters from Dublin and Prestwick which airlted senior fire chiefs to provide them with an aerial view of the raging inferno so they could plan the on-the-ground response.Keen to do its part, the Newcastle community stepped up to help donating food and drink to the emergency services with an appeal launched by schoolboy Charlie Thompson raising over pound, to thank firefighters for their efforts.Stormont environment minister Edwin Poots and health minister Robin Swann were both in Newcastle last weekend to thank firefighters for the work they were doing with senior fire chiefs appealing to people to ensure nothing like this ever happens again.Mr Poots confirmed that the damage to the arearsquos rich bioersity spread over three and a half square kilometres could potentially take years to recover and said he was ldquoheart-broken and sickened by the events which unfolded last Friday night.ldquoIt is hard to grasp the scale of the fire and the devastation that occurred. While we do not know the full scale of the impact of the fire at this stage, we do know that it will be signicant for the environment and tourism economy that thrives on the unique natural beauty of this renowned area, he added.South Down MP Chris Hazzard described images of the fire encircling the Mournes as ldquoshocking and said confirmation the blaze was deliberate ldquosickens you to the heart of your stomach someone would be so reckless to skulk about in the middle of the night to set fire ti such a precious environmental habitat.He declared: ldquoMake no mistake, these arsonists should be dealt with in the exact same way asthey had set fire to a public building.Mr Hazzard also said it was not enough for the environment minister to ldquomaybe introduce fines for such behaviour.He said there was also a need for better management of the Mournes, highlighting the need for increased finances to be provided to the Mourne Heritage Trust and Newry, Mourne and Down Council to help them deal with a ldquoreally sensitive and fragile environment.Meanwhile fire chiefs say everyone must work hard to prevent fires like those which ravaged the Mournes last weekend from ever happening again,.They have appealed to the public to do all they can to help to prevent signicant environmental damage and placing a major strain on Fire and Rescue Service resources..prettyPhoto

title: Down Leisure Centre to reopen doors again
story: DOWN Leisure Centre in Downpatrick reopens to the public this Friday.Newry, Mourne and Down Council has confirmed that a number of its leisure facilities will be back in use as part of the continued easing of lockdown restrictions across the area.In addition to the leisure complexrsquos pool reopening, gym users will also be able toto the Market Street complex as part of the phased reopening of indoor leisure facilities which will be in line with current Covid- guidelines.Members can book gym and swim slots in advance online and on the NMD Be Active app.In addition, bookings can also be made by telephone on    between from the start of this week until tomorrow between am and pm.Leisure centre members and users are being asked to keep an eye online at https:www.newrymournedown.org leisure-facilities and on the local authorityrsquos social media channels for further details.Ahead of this Fridayrsquos reopening, the organisation wants to reassure ing members that, for their safety, an enhanced cleaning regime will be in place.There will also be clear visible guidelines about cleanliness and reminders of personal responsibility throughout the facilities.Council chairwoman Laura Devlin said the local authority was delighted to see theof some outdoor sports training and welcomes the latest announcement from the Northern Ireland Executive allowing leisure centre doors to reopen once again.ldquoI know the staff within our leisure centres will do all they can to accommodate as many people as possible while ensuring adherence to government guidance so that everyone can feel as safe as possible, she said.ldquoI know many of us have found the most recent lockdown restrictions dficult and will see the reopening of our leisure centres as a really positive step in the recovery of our local community..prettyPhoto

title: Down ready for examination from Mayo in National League
story: INTER-COUNTY action is finally ready to recommence as the Down senior menrsquos team prepare for theirto competitive football in the National League.The Mourne county will begin their Division  campaign on Saturday, May .The four isions within the league will each be split into two groups ndash north and south ndash meaning Down will go head-to-head with Mayo, Westmeath and Meath.Down begin their back-to-back promotion aspirations as they travel to Mayo for a pm throw-in at MacHale Park.The following Sunday, they take on Meath at the neutral Athletic Grounds in Armagh, this time with a later start at .pm.Down then face off against Westmeath at Cusack Park in Mullingar on Saturday, May , with the throw-in pencilled in for .pm.Despite the Mourne men undergoing a serious revamp in recent times as they secured promotion from Division  at the end of last year, they have not been without controversy.Down previously accepted a punishment of losing a home fixture in this yearrsquos league due to breaching Covid- guidelines by gathering a large training group in early January.This is why their second league game against Meath has been moved to neutral Armagh.Manager Paddy Tally was also handed an initial -week suspension as a result of the collective training, but this was subsequently reduced to eight weeks.ldquoI think the whole thing has become a bit of a circus, said Tally.ldquoItrsquos not a nice thing to be dragged through the press and to be seen as some sort of a lawbreaker and some sort of an enemy of the public, which wersquore certainly not, he added.The ban concluded earlier this month and therefore will not affect Tallyrsquos involvement when the league commences.Down will be hoping to use their opening league game as an early indicator for the level of competition in store for them this year, as well as preparation for a new look gaelic gamesunder Covid- regulations.Down face Donegal at Paacuteirc Elser in the preliminary round of the Ulster Championship on Sunday, June .Both counties will have a dficult pathway to claim the Anglo-Celt, with the winners going on to lock horns with Derry in the quarter-finals.Down and Donegal last met in the provincial series in  when Donegal made light work of a struggling Mourne outfit.However, Down have looked a dferent team under the appointment of Tally and it is something that Donegal boss Declan Bonner has not overlooked.ldquoIt is going to be a battle in Newry and Paddy Tally has come in and really ramped them up, said Bonner.ldquoThis is going to be a real test going in to play Down in Newry with all its great tradition and this Down team are playing with all the swagger and self-belief of the Down teams of old, he added.Meanwhile, Down hurlers begin their league campaign on Saturday, May , against Kerry at Austin Stack Park.They will also face Carlow, Wicklow, Offaly and Meath throughout the upcoming weeks.Down have also drawn Kerry and Meath in this yearrsquos Joe McDonagh Cup, which will be run under a new format with six teams, instead of five as was previous the case, ided into two groups of three. This comes after both of last yearrsquos Christy Ring Cup finalists, Down and Kildare, were promoted.Each team will play one home and one away match with the top placed in each group advancing to the final and the winner promoted to the Leinster SHC in .The bottom-placed teams in each group will play off with the loser demoted to the Christy Ring Cup..prettyPhoto

title: East Down AC get back to the basics
story: LAST weekend saw the first official racing since the lockdown which kicked in somewhat abruptly in the third week in December.Glenn Grant from ChampionChip Ireland had been hosting a series of races at ious venues over the autumn months but his schedule ground to a halt when Covid- restrictions were reintroduced.All runners had already received their numbers so they were advised that their entry would be held over until events were allowed to recommence. Indeed the maze lsquofestival of runningrsquo had been pushed back twice so Glenn had a ready supply of entrants poised to swing into action once the NI Executive indicated that ato competitive sport was on the cards.There had been a sense of growing anticipation and even though these races were announced with short notice, there were few who turned down the chance to take part.The venue was set at Down Royal with a half marathon distance held on the Saturday and K races on the Sunday.Unfortunately it was not possible to accommodate new entries as the organisers had to work with the overall cap of  attendees which had to include runners and all officials. The races were split into waves according to projected finish times and runners were warned that they were only to be on site for the duration of their wave and there were no additional spectators.Declan Teague was in the first half marathon wave aimed at those who were able to complete the . miles in one hour  minutes or less.He reported back that the course was four laps, a mix of country roads around the area and then part of the racecourse perimeter track.He added that it was a beautul morning to be out racing but there was a strong headwind on a two mile uphill stretch each lap, which was tough going.He was more than happy to record a time of :: which placed him th overall in the field of  once the times were ranked. Lockdown has obviously not been detrimental to this consistent performer.Next day conditions were also ideal for those ready to toe the line. EDAC had three runners out to give the K a go.Conaill MacNabb more often seen in triathlons is a new recruit to our club so he was racing in EDAC colours for the first time.In fact, he was so recently signed up that he had to borrow a vest but hopefully this is the first of many races for the club as he has talent to spare as a runner.His time of . was good enough for th place out of  and stands as a personal best for now.With a few more races under his belt it will not be that long until he betters this. Welcome to the club, Conaill.Jonny Holmes has been gradually building back up since a minor operation a few months ago and so was gratied to record a sub  minute timein order to edge back to his previous form. He has been ticking over with the EDAC lockdown plan and ious challenges so is ready now to push himself towards the next goal.His personal best stands at . so that is back in sight and given his competitive approach a sub  is not an impossible goal.Sharon Madine was the sole female to fly the EDAC flag. She trains hard and loves racing but she says that she went out a bit too hard in the first mile and then suffered in the final stretch.It may not have been ideal as far as pacing is concerned but her actual time of . wasnrsquot far outside her previous personal best so she canrsquot be too hard on herself.It seems likely that a sub  minute K is on the horizon. Great running all round from Team EDAC and plenty of goals ahead.It is uplting to see results and race photos appearing on social media and with any luck this will once again become a regular occurrence.ChampionChip have let it be known that their other postponed event is going to be staged in the near future andthey can allow some new entries it is sure to be sold out in no time so keep a lookoutyou are hoping to get involved..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 2%2C 2001
story: DOWNPATRICK ndash A Downpatrick firefighter who saved the lives of a local mother and her two children received a rare bravery award last week.James Fitzpatrick was presented with the award during a ceremony at Downpatrick Police Station on Thursday night.The recognition comes several months after the dedicated fireman came across a fire on his way to the Downpatrick Station to answer a call.On his way to the town centre to join the fire-fighting team, James came across a house at Racecourse Road with smoke billowing from its windows.Using a wheelie bin to reach an upstairs window, he brought Brenda Murphy and her daughters, Aimee and Ashlynne, to safety.Jamesrsquo efforts led Down Districtrsquos Divisional Fire Officer, Mr John Allen, to nominate him for the awards scheme which is run by the Royal Humane Society for Saving Le from Fire.Mr Allen admits that it is the first time, since he took up his post in the area, that he has been encouraged to nominate a firefighter for the award.ldquoI think Jamesrsquo actions typy the highest standards that we would expect from a firefighter, he said.ldquoHe stayed calm under pressure, he used the equipment available to him and as a result of these actions three people are now walking around with a quality of le which they may not have otherwise had.NEWCASTLE ndash Newcastle is to get a new ambulance base. Work to provide the -hour facility at the Castlewellan Road area in the town is expected to begin shortly and be completed before the end of the summer.The Ambulance Service has this week submitted plans to redevelop a former warehouse in the resort to provide the new station and hopes local planners will process the application as quickly as possible.A new base for Newcastle was first identied a number of years ago and while it was hoped the station would have opened before now, Ambulance Service officials have confirmed they plan to concentrate all their efforts on the resort to ensure the new facility is up and running as soon as possible.Mr Keith Stewart, the Ambulance Servicersquos area station manager, said once operational, the Newcastle base will play a key role in the area and provide improved response times for patients.CROSSGAR ndash A group of Crossgar residents, who failed in a High Court bid to overturn a planning decision allowing the expansion of a turkey plant near their homes, have this week vowed to fight on.The Cluntagh Road residents have confirmed they now plan to take their case to the Commissioner for Complaints.Residents went to the High Court after planning permission was granted last year allowing Hillfarm Turkeys to expand its processing operation.They said they are concerned about the size and scale of the plant and suggested the operation should be relocated away from the Cluntagh Road area to an industrial park.Last December, the residents claimed they had been denied the right of a public inquiry and confirmed that in addition to pursuing the legal challenge, they also planned to raise the issue with the Commissioner for Complaints.BALLYNAHINCH ndash An up and coming Ballynahinch business woman has recently won through to the final of the prestigious Shell LiveWIRE Young Business Awards.Emma McGrath will compete with seven other finalists at the prestigious event, on May  at Belfast Castle, which recognises Northern Irelandrsquos most promising young business talent.Emma has developed tone.art to offer a range of services to iniduals and businesses. With a heavy focus on art rental, she offers clients a cost effective and flexible means of displaying contemporary art work, created by artists working throughout Ireland.Rental periods last from three to six months, which has the benefit of allowing clients to change the entire look and feel of their office in one easy step.Emmarsquos venture, which also offers sales, commissions, portraits, corporate gts and architectural design consultancy, is fast becoming an important link between businesses and artists from all over the Province.KILLYLEAGH ndash The SDLPrsquos electoral candidate for the Rowallane area has this week called for more social housing to be made available in Killyleagh.Pointing out that  housing applicants were on a waiting list for the Shrigley and Killyleagh area, Mrs Kathleen Stockton, said these statistics proved there was a need for more housing units.She said the Housing Executive needed to indicate where new housing could be located and should ensure that new dwellings are built.ldquoI fully accept that some of that housing need will be meet by the  units for the elderly which are under construction at Cross Street and this should release some family housing for re-letting, she said.ldquoAt the same time, the Housing Executive as the comprehensive housing authority needs to ensure that the deficit is met in some form.COMBER ndash Fans of hit television programme lsquoBig Brotherrsquo and other fly-on-the-wall documentaries should hurry along to the Wildfowl and Wetlands Centre at Castle Espie, near Comber.For visitors to the local venue over the next month or so will be able to spy on a very special house and its occupants as a live video link has been set up to the inside of a blue titrsquos nesting box.Visitors will be transfixed as they watch two very busy parents who are getting ready for the arrival of their first eggs.A spokesman from the centre said docu-soaps just wonrsquot have the same appeal after watching the thrilling events for real at the Ballydrain Road centre.ldquoThe struggle will be on to find enough insects to feed the hungry mouths in chilly weather. The battle between brothers and sisters to get enough food and the more mundane, but still fascinating happenings, such as housework to keep the nest spick and span will make compulsive viewing, he said.The spotlight may be on this one nest box, but the tasks, challenges and forfeits that face the occupants Big Brother-style will be repeated in private all across the reserve, and at this early stage in the breeding season  of the centrersquos boxes are being used.KILLINCHY ndash Down Council chairman Albert Colmer has this week welcomed news that the Carpets International factory in Killinchy will not be closing.Mr Colmer said he was delighted the plant will not be shut as part of a major restructuring and downsizing operation by its American owners.Mr Colmer, who earlier this year was appointed to a special group set up to seek talks with factoryrsquos owners, says the fact over  jobs will not be lost is a great boost for the workforce and the arearsquos economy.The council chairman said the majority of the staff at the factory are from the Killyleagh and surrounding areas and he praised their dedication and commitment.ldquoTwo years ago the Killinchy plant was on the brink of closure and the fact that it is to continue playing a key role in the carpet manufacturing industry is a tribute to the local workers and managers at the plant, he said.ldquoThe factoryrsquos owners have warned that while the Killinchy plant will remain open, in tandem with is sister operation in Donaghadee, it is essential it continues to achieve higher efficiencies in order to compete in the marketplace and I am sure the staff have no dficulty with this at all.Mr Colmer said the consequences for the local economythe plant had closed its doors would have been ldquotoo horric to contemplate..prettyPhoto

title: Hair we go – salons reopen after lockdown
story: LOCAL hairdressers have welcomed ato business following the easing of lockdown restrictions.Salons are finally back to cutting and styling after a four month layoff.Andrew Maginn, owner of Ace Barbers in Downpatrick said the lockdown was a ldquoreal struggle given that he only opened in August .ldquoEverything was so stop-start but hopefully thatrsquos all behind us now. Itrsquos fantastic to get back, I just want us to stay this way, said Andrew.Despite the long absence, Andrewrsquos clientele remained as loyal as ever as his reopening time slots for appointments were fully booked.ldquoI stayed in touch with my customers over social media. In terms of traditional barbers, Irsquom the quickest and cheapest about, he quipped.ldquoOnce you set a fair price the customers will always remain loyal to you.Andrew has made use of the time off during the pandemic to remodel his salon in time for reopening.ldquoPeople walking by Ace Barbers the last few months could see the work we are putting in here. They can see we are improving the facilities everyday, said Andrew.Staff at McCartanrsquos in Market Street say they are ldquojust glad to see all of their customers again.Proprietor Joan Burns said: ldquoItrsquos great to see both men and women back into the salon. We missed our loyal customers so much, itrsquos amazing to see them back smiling and catching up with them.The salon closed its doors four months ago but now the staff are firmly setting their sight on a hopeful future ahead.ldquoWe are getting back into the swing of things. Hopefully the worst is behind us, we want our doors to be open for a very long time, said Joan.Downpatrick-based barbers Thee Menrsquos Room have also welcomed lsquoato some sort of normalityrsquo following the lting of restrictions.Salon manager Rian Dyer said: ldquoItrsquos nice to actually see people rather than being in the house by yourself. To chat to the customers again is great, I think itrsquos important for everyonersquos health that we are allowed to safely socialise again.As per the Executive, A person must not provide a close contact service unless an appointment to provide the service has been booked in advance by online communication, telephone, text or electronic messaging.Thee Menrsquos Room are making use of their online booking system which customers can use to choose a date, time and which barber they want to cut their hair. This can be found on their website or through their social media accounts.ldquoThe system is great and handy to use. Itrsquos another way wersquove been able to reduce risk and make people feel more comfortable, said Rian.Customer Patrick Crane said: ldquoItrsquos great to be back in the barberrsquos chair. I alwayrsquos feel welcomed with the guys here and I wouldnrsquot go anywhere ..prettyPhoto

title: New owner of St Michael’s Parish Centre
story: A NEW owner will take over St Michaelrsquos Parish Centre in Downpatrick this weekend.The Irish Street building ndash which boasted a  seater theatre in its top floor ndash was once the social hub for parishioners.It was sold for pound, with some of the funds already erted into much-needed maintenance projects.Fr John Murray, PP, explained the need for the parish centre had declined and it was not purpose-built for todayrsquos parish needs.ldquoThe front of the building is listed andyou were to go to a modern parish centre, you would find that it has wheelchair access and ours hasnrsquot, he said.ldquoIt was once used as a girlsrsquo school by the Sisters of Mercy and then it was developed as a parish centre.ldquoHowever, in later years, the parish has not been using it that much and it was costing between pound, to pound, to run each year. Any groups who were using it have now found alternative accommodation.Fr Murray said that during the Troubles the parish centre provided a safe haven for parish and cultural and social activities but plays and concerts stopped being hosted there about  years ago.ldquoParish le has changed, said Fr Murray. ldquoWhen the Troubles were on, people were afraid to venture too far so they went to Mass on Sunday, went to the bingo at the Parish Centre on Friday or to a dance.ldquoWhen the Troubles ended, people went back out to the bright lights of the city and we canrsquot compete with the money thatrsquos put into clubs. A lot of parish centres have died a death and even the ones that are going well are finding things hard.Fr Murray said that several interesting items were found in the buildings stores when they were clearing it out.ldquoDownpatrick Silver and Reed Band used to rehearse in the hall and we found a baton and a drum. We gave the drum to Fr Brendan Smyth, the parish priest in Crossgar, as his father banged that drum and he was delighted to have received it, he said.ldquoAlso, we found a lovely statue of St Joseph which was over  years old and had been well fixed to a wall at the back of the building. We removed it and itrsquos now standing in front of St Patrickrsquos Church all brightly repainted.Fr Murray also mentioned the parishrsquos hope that a suitable arrangement would be found for the former Sisters of Mercy convent which sits beside St Patrickrsquos Church.The Sisters of Mercy Congregation gave the building to Sr Consilio, which runs the Cuan Mhuire addiction recovery centre in Newry, in . However, St Consilio decided last year that it was unable to take on the Downpatrick building on along with its other commitments and offered it to the parish.Fr Murray said: ldquoThere are still ongoing discussions within the parish about the convent. However, we would hope that whatever happens with the convent building that it will be in keeping and in harmony with neighbouring our church..prettyPhoto

title: Scene ‘deeply distressing’
story: THE dramatic images of the Mournes burning on Friday evening sparked an immediate response from senior politicians who expressed shock at the photographs they were witnessing.First Minister Arlene Foster tweeted ldquothis is devastating and tragic and the impact on wildle and flora is unimaginable while Deputy First Minister Michelle OrsquoNeill thanked the emergency services for all they were doing to ldquoprotect the beauty of the Mournes and save wildle.Northern Ireland Secretary Brandon Lewis described the scenes in the Mournes as ldquodeeply distressing at one of the regionrsquos most beautul landmarks and also paid tribute to the firefighters at the scene.Local political condemnation has been led by South Down MP Chris Hazzard, MLAs and local councillors.Mr Hazzard said the community was both ldquoshocked and angry at the impact of the blaze on a popular spot with visitors, particularly after the impact of the coronavirus pandemic.ldquoPeople will have seen the shocking images the Mournes looked like a range of volcanos that were erupting, he said.ldquoThere was shock, but also anger in the community that here we are again, another event we have to deal with. Obviously we have been dealing with Covid-, but there was also a large flood last year in Newcastle and now wersquore going to have to pick up the pieces after the fire.ldquoTherersquos not too many people who go into the Mournes a am on a Friday morning for a barbecue, he declared. ldquoWhat we need to see now is a moratorium on all gorse burning right across the island.South Down MLA Colin McGrath said he believed legislators need to ensure that structures are put in place to prevent such a devastating fire from happening again, highlighting the need for an an all-island strategy to address wildfires, with the focus on how they can be prevented and how people can be educated better about land management.Paying tribute to the bravery and determination of those tackling the blaze, he said he feared the huge fire will not only have a devastating impact on the natural landscape, but also the Newcastle economy that relies so heavily on tourism associated with the Mournes.ldquoHaving met with the Fire and Rescue Service it is clear that they are doing everything they can to combat these blazes. However, the issue of gorse and wildfires is something that affects our entire island and our response to it cannot just be a reaction to every outbreak of fire but a measured response that attempts to understand why these fires are happening so often and ultimately to prevent them, he continued.ldquoThat is why I tabled an oral question at the Assembly on Monday to the Health Minister asking for an all-island strategy to specically address the prevention, response, post investigation analysis of such fires and,necessary, what repercussions there would be for those who perpetrate these fires.Mr McGrath added: ldquoWhile gorse and wildfires do not recognise borders, they do recognise barriers. We have seen instances in the past where the blocking of land masses has ensured that fires were not able to get a grasp where they would have caused untold damage had this not been the case.Slieve Croob councillor Andy McMurray also thanked firefighters and revealed that he watched the fire spread from the Glen Fofanny area, across Leganabruchan and Millstone on Friday evening towards Thomasrsquos Mountain which was ldquoencircled in apocalyptic flames.He said the fact the fire covered such a distance underlines the intense ferocity of the blaze and seeing how close it came to the boundary of Donard Forest really puts into perspective the work of all those involved in the emergency response.Cllr McMurray said he took time off work last Friday morning to do a litter pick along the Bloody Bridge River and collected a number of discarded barbecues.He continued: ldquoThat people are taking these into the hills in the first place is a nonsense. But to do so during such a dry spell as we are experiencing and then only to leave them behind is just the height of irresponsibility and ignorance.ldquoThere are many factors which give rise to the wildfire scenario we have found ourselves in. The reality is that we have experienced this before only a few years ago in Tullybrannigan and last year at Dollyrsquos Brae near Castlewellan.Cllr McMurray said emergency and local agencies needed to receive support from Stormont andWestminster to be in position to regularly deal and investigate fires which are ldquocrimes against our natural habitat and need to be forensically examined in order establish responsibility.He added: ldquoFrom there, due process should be followed while in the longer term there is a need to explorethere are environmental management strategies which can be adopted to reduce the chances of such events happening.Mournes councillor Glyn Hanna has spoken of his shock at seeing images of the wildfires.He said he feared it may take years for the Mournes to recover from the devastation.ldquoThe images of fire on the mountains reminded me of similar pictures of lava flowing from volcanoes in Iceland, he said.ldquoThe images of Donard were just shocking, andthis was started deliberately then whoever did it should be ashamed.ldquoStarting fires on the mountains is no joke and is nothing more than a criminal act putting people in danger for no reason, Cllr Hanna added..prettyPhoto

title: Super supporter John signs off 18th book on Manchester United
story: CARRYDUFF Manchester United Supportersrsquo Club branch secretary John White has released his th book about his beloved team.lsquoManchester United ndash The Making of a Football Dynastyrsquo is the latest instalment of Johnrsquos impressive book series in which he reviews the story behind  of their past matches.This book is part of a two volume set, with  games being detailed in each.The games could be substantial for a number of reasons, such as a notable playerrsquos debut, a record scoreline, a controversial moment and so on.ldquoThis is a book which will teach United fans the history of the club in a way that has never been approached before, said John.ldquoThere is a lot of interesting trivia mixed-in about players, the opposition, the competition and I end every game with a special did you know that The author insists this isnrsquot a ldquoglory glory Manchester United book, but rather it is one of ldquoovercoming adversity and learning.The Red Devils super-fan began writing about his favourite team whilst travelling to matches with the cross-community supportersrsquo club  years ago. The club is now recognised officially as the fth biggest Manchester United supportersrsquo club in the world.ldquoI set up the club in  and at that stage we used to go from Belfast to Stranraer on the boat, then take a coach to Manchester, said John.ldquoThat road trip is  miles approximately, so I thought I should do a wee quiz on the coach just to pass time. I made up a round of questions and we went from there.ldquoAfter a few seasons we had over  questions so I decided to write a Manchester United quiz book in .John initially struggled to gain any support from publishers until he received a helping hand from none other than Manchester United manager Sir Alex Ferguson himself.ldquoI asked Sir Alex at an annual supportersrsquo club meetinghe would do a foreword for my book, he explained.ldquoI asked him to endorsed it and after he agreed I recontacted Unitedrsquos official publishers, Andre Deutsch.ldquoThey took on the book and it was selling in Old Trafford the next week, he added.John has since gone from strength to strength and written a number of sports books with many Northern Irish personalities such as George Best, Eamonn Holmes and Barry McGuigan adding forewords to help him along the way.His latest release includes a foreword by former Northern Ireland and United star Norman Whiteside.Johnrsquos new book is available now to purchase on Amazon..prettyPhoto

title: The potential of St Patrick’s Way walk
story: IRISH pilgrimage sites such as St Patrickrsquos Way in Downpatrick could be successfully developed with the right marketing strategy, according to Irish writer and broadcaster Mary Kenny.The veteran journalist made the remarks in Patrickrsquos Podcast, a new initiative to mark the th anniversary of the St Patrickrsquos Centre.Speaking to pilgrim guides Martina Purdy, a former BBC correspondent, and Elaine Kelly, a former barrister, Kenny pointed out that pilgrimage had a fundamental human attractive even to people of no faith.She pointed to the success of Wild Atlantic Way marketing campaign had been on the west coast of Ireland.ldquoIreland could develop its pilgrimage potential much more and much better, she said.Kennyis still writing columns for the Irish Independent and continues to have a fascination with history.She said that, post lockdown, she would love to come and visit the sites in Downpatrick associated with St Patrick.ldquoI think Patrick is having a terric revival and will have as we live in a very confusing time in terms of faith and politics in the north and south of Ireland, she remarked.ldquoIn those tensions, the great thing is to go back to the source and the fundamental and Patrick is that source and the scholarship around him is now terric.She also expressed hope that Irelandrsquos Christian heritage would flourish again and the hostility towards faith among some in the Irish Government would give way to respect.Kenny, who also writes a column for the Irish Catholic, is one of the founders of the Womenrsquos Liberation Movement in Ireland.In the podcast, shared her views on modern feminism. She said a fundamental error was a ldquorigid idea of equality which ignored the dferences in men and women.Dr Tim Campbell, director of the St Patrick Centre, welcomed Kennyrsquos remarks on pilgrimage.ldquoWe have a world class product celebrated in every country in the world each year and now offer the only guided Camino in Ireland, he said.ldquoThe ideal of a lsquoslowcationrsquo and taking time to enjoy companionship outdoors in small groups and have light exercise is the perfect way to come out of lockdown.The podcast is now available on Saint Patrickrsquos Centre website.The former broadcaster Gerry Kelly has also agreed to take part in the podcast and his interview will be posted this Friday..prettyPhoto

title: Top three finish for Shimna student in poetry contest
story: A STUDENT from Shimna Integrated College in Newcastle has come third in an Ulster University poetry competition.Nancy OrsquoBaoill-Coylersquos poem Contamination was commended by the universityrsquos English team in a high quality array of entries received.The A Level student wrote the poem while she was on remote learning.Principal Kevin Lambe said: ldquoSo many of our students have taken the opportunity of lockdown to achieve more and Nancyrsquos success with her very moving and challenging poem is one of our best examples. We are very proud of her..prettyPhoto

title: Waterworth to depart Linfield
story: ANDY Waterworth is preparing for le after Linfield when he departs at the end of the season.The Crossgar striker is currently considering his options after his current club look set to make the switch from part-time to full-time next year.The prolic footballer has made  appearances for Linfield and found the net  times since signing from Glentoran in May .Waterworthwill not be short of choices, with Lurgan-based Glenavon rumoured to be highly interested.ldquoIrsquove spoken to a few clubs. I canrsquot go full-time with Linfield, even for a year, said Waterworth.ldquoAt the age of  it wouldnrsquot be right for me to give up my working career for one year full-time with Linfield.The striker works in coaching education with the Irish FA and is currently assisting Northern Ireland U- boss Gerard Lyttle as the national team prepare for their Euro  championship qualiers in October later this year.Recently, Linfieldrsquos club record goalscorer in Europe helpedNorthern Ireland U-s at a training camp in Belfast alongside Killyleagh goalkeeper Conor Brennan.Despite the coaching role, Waterworth still believes he has a lot to offer on the pitch.ldquoI still feel Irsquom a footballer on a Saturday and I can still contribute despite the ageing process, he said.ldquoI can give another club a year of my time and we can see how it develops. At the moment Irsquom not turning my back on playing but this season isnrsquot done yet.Linfield are hoping to clinch a th league championship and currently sit top of the NIFL Premiership, seven points clear of nearest rivals Glentoran.On a personal note, this will be Waterworthrsquos fth league titlehis team can close out the season on top of the table.ldquoIrsquod love to go out on a high and win a fth league title, but therersquos a lot of work to be done before that happens and the players will not take their eye off the ball, he said.ldquoMy full focus is still on winning trophies with Linfield. Irsquom fully committed to the club and therersquos huge respect there.The prolic footballer has made  appearances for Linfield and found the net  times since signing from Glentoran in May .Waterworth fully understands the clubrsquos decision to progress and spoke without regret in his decision to move on.ldquoIt will be hard to leave WLinfield but I have huge respect for the club chairman, Roy McGivern, and managingdirector Pat Fenlon, all the players and staff, and I totally understand the direction the club is going in, said Waterworth.ldquoIrsquom a football man, I take the game seriously and I believe Linfield are doing the right thing moving ahead with the full-time ethos, he added.Waterworth now sets his sight on a crucial top of the table clash as Linfield take on his former club Glentoran this Saturday, in what could prove to be a pivotal deciding match in this yearrsquos Premiership..prettyPhoto

title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityThe Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. Cows grazed outdoors using a Lely Grazeway This website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: superb quality entries at second annual calf fair
story: As a subscriber, you are shown % lessThose ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local servicesThese adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local communityBreed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast.Speaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and ten native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and chairman David Connolly said: Itrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.French judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors.ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.ABERDEEN ANGUSA strong entry of Aberdeen Angus calves were judged by William McLaren from the noted Netherton Herd based at Blackford in Perthshire.Stealing the limelight in the junior section was the -month-old heer, Home Farm Ebony Stunner bred by Fintan Keown, Belleek. She is a daughter of the three-times All Ireland champion Rosemead Karona, and was reserve heer calf champion at the breed clubrsquos calf show a few weeks ago.HEREFORDTaking the reserve junior award was David Wilson, Magheraveely, with the April  heer Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master.Heer born between    and    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Prettymaid th by Ballyaville LelinerBull born after    - , John and William McMordie, Solpoll  National by Solpoll  Dynamite , David Wilson, Lisrace Lumberjack th by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Kadar by Mara Flook.Heer born after    - , David Wilson, Lisrace Crystal by Knockmountage Master , Mervyn Richmond, Corraback Guenevere th by Mara Flook.IRISH MOILEDThe Irish Moiled classes were judged by Trevor Chadwick from County Offaly. Taking the reserve senior award was the October  Burren Lady, a Knowehead Reuben daughter bred by Nigel Edwards and Michelle McCauley.,The Edwards and McCauley partnership also secured the junior championship at the one-day show with the seven-month-old bull Curraghnakeely Super Duper. CHAROLAISWelshman Arwel Owen placed the strong line-up of Charolais at the Pedigree Calf Fair. Stuart and David Bothwell, Ballinamallard, secured the reserve senior championship with the October  Killadeas Lara, a Goldies Usher daughter out of the home-bred Killadeas Dainty.Heer born between    and    ndash  Gilbert Crawford, Coolnaslee Lucybella by Goldstar Hugo , Stuart and David Bothwell, Killadeas Lara by Goldies Usher.Heer born between    and    ndash , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Missy by Vexour FreddyBull calf born after    ndash , WD  JA Connolly, Brigadoon Marverick by Goldies Icon , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Myboy by Hillviewfarm Perfect ,Will Short, Woodpark Marcus by Deeside Gulliver ET.Heer calf born after    ndash , WD and JA Connolly, Brigadoon Milan by Goldies Icon , Harold Stubbs and Alan Burleigh, Derryharney Mygirl by Blelack Blackberet , Jack Smyth, Bessiebell Molly ET by Newhouse Bigal.LIMOUSINBull born between    and    ndash , D and R McFarland, Rayderjem Maverick by Haltclfe DoctorSIMMENTALScottish breeder Iain Green from the noted Corskie Herd in Morayshire praised the quality of Simmentals at the one-day show. Catching his eye to take the senior championship plaudits was the -month-old Scribby Farms George, an Omorga Volvo son, bred by Keith and Andrea Nelson from Rosslea.Pat Kelly, and son Frank, Tempo, secured the junior championship award with the ten-month-old bull Ashland Humdinger. Also by Dermotstown Delboy, he is bred from Ashland Lady Diamond th ndash one of  cows in the herd. Claiming the reserve junior title was the January  Curaheen Apostle son Drumlone Hotrod exhibited by Kenny Veitch, Lisbellaw.Bull born between    and    - , Keith Nelson, Scribby Farms George by Omorga VolvoHeer born between    and    - , Duncan McDowell, Castlemount Wiekel by Longbeach Darius , Shane and Paul McDonald, Coolcran Lady Grainne by Ashland BrandyBull born between    and    - , Pat and Frank Kelly, Ashland Humdinger by Dermotstown Delboy , Kenneth Veitch, Drumlone Hotrod by Curaheen ApostleHeer born between    and    -, Stephen Millar, Glenock Highway by Kilbride Farm Newry , E OrsquoNeill, Drumcoote Daisybell by Scottish Neff.Bull calf born after    -, Andrew Clarke, Beaghey Harrison by Wroxall Cocker-Leeky-Soup , Keith Nelson, Scribby Farms Hero by Omorga Volvo.Heer calf born after     - , William Nelson, Drumacritten Heidi by Dermotstown DelboyBRITISH BLONDEHeer born between    and    - , Conor Savage, Gledney Kathryn by Fronfedw Arawn , Johnston Family, Ballymacan Mabel by Lockhead Tyson , Brian McGartland Drumnafern Lola by Budore Emo.Bull born after    - , Norman McKnight, Silverwood Mark by Ardmore Gargoyle , Norman McKnight, Silverwood Murry by Ardmore Gargoyle , Johnston Family, Ballymacan Mark by Lockhead Tyson.Heer born after    ndash , Conor Savage, Gledney Keva by Drumraymond Grafter , Norman McKnight, Silverwood Molly by Ardmore Gargoyle , Johnston Family, Ballymacan Misty by Clondown Eddie.BRITISH BLUEThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: edwin poots publishes dup leadership manifesto heres a summary of what he promises to do if elected new leader
story: Stormont Agriculture Minister Edwin Poots threatens legal action over NI Protocol   Councillor: I took part in illegal UVF UDA-linked parade – and I don’t careNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsEdwin Poots publishes DUP leadership manesto - heres a summary of what he promises to doelected new leaderEdwin Poots has published DUP leadership manesto.By Andrew QuinnWednesday, th May , : pm  "       "  Mr. Poots was the first person to put himself forward as a possible successor to current leader and First Minister, Arlene Foster.Sir. Jeffrey Donaldson has also confirmed he is to contest the leadership race.The election is due to be held on Friday May , .   " fill"#ea"  to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting..." "" width"" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMwNjAODkz.jpg width w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMwNjAODkz.jpg width w" layout"intrinsic" i-amphtml-ssr data-hero class"i-amphtml-layout-intrinsic i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"intrinsic"" fallback layout"responsive" "" width"" src" img placeholder.png" class"i-amphtml-layout-responsive i-amphtml-layout-size-defined" i-amphtml-layout"responsive"" src"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMwNjAODkz.jpg width" srcset"https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMwNjAODkz.jpg width w, https:www.newsletter webimg TUFZMTMwNjAODkz.jpg width w"Edwin Poots pictured at Stormont last week. Mr. Poots is calling the document his Manesto for Reform and indeed, the opening line includes both the words "revitalise" and "rebuild".A few paragraphs later Mr. Poots says the DUP must be "restructured and re-energised" and confirmed thatelected he will separate the position of leader and First Minister for Northern Ireland stating "one person cannot do justice to both demanding jobs".If successful, Mr. Poots says he would use his position as party leader to "oversee the work of a new ministerial team and the day-to-day management of the party".Mr. Poots goes on to tell his fellow party members that one of his main priorities as leader would be to give a "resounding response" to any suggestion of a border poll on Irish unity.Mr. Poots also claims he has a "plan that will transform the DUP structure and s" but offers no details on what his plan will look like.In terms of the Northern Ireland Protocol, Mr. Poots sets out an action plan in which he says he would work to "systematically undermine and strip away all aspects of it".Engagement across all levels of unionism and loyalism is also high on Mr. Poots list of priorities.Mr. Poots says he would also launch pro-union initiatives that would include: a Unionist convention of poltical and civil unionism a pro-union strategic think tank that would work towards building support for the union and thereby avoid a border poll.The current Agriculture Minister also says he would set-up a pro-union foundation which would support initiatives designed to strengthen the union.In the final section of the manesto, Mr. Poots sets out his priorities for both the DUP as a party and his priorities for government.In terms of priorities for the party, Mr. Poots lists implementation of his Manesto for Reform as his number one objective.An independent review of the DUP would also be one of Mr. Poots prioritieselected leader and he says he would also want to see "internal DUP engagement with every Association".Concerning his priorities for government Mr. Poots says as DUP leader he would seek to expose "republican propaganda and shameless populism".Mr. Poots also says he will oversee the DUPs new ministerial team and develop a strategy to see the development of "DUP initiatives covering all aspects of devolved government".The manesto ends with a pledge to improve the effectiveness between elected DUP representatives in Stormont and Westminster.---A message from the Editor:Thank you for reading this story on our website. title: in a withering critique of how the dup is run edwin poots promises to end secrecy and to transform party
story: Sinn Fein say Bobby Sands ‘fully expected to die on the hunger strike’ and ‘changed his mind’ about where he wanted buried   Councillor: I took part in illegal UVF UDA-linked parade – and I don’t careNewsLatestTraffic and TravelCrimeWeatherPoliticsBusinessEducationHealthOpinionPeopleRead ThisSportFootballMotorcyclingRugby UnionOther SportOpinionWhats OnThings To DoArts and EntertainmentNightleRetroLestyleEating OutCarsHomes and GardensHomes and GardensCoronaviruse-PaperFarmingRecommendedPuzzlesPublic NoticesNewsPoliticsIn a withering critique of how the DUP is run, Edwin Poots promises to end secrecy and to ‘transform’ partyEdwin Poots has pledged to end secrecy within the DUP and radically reform how the party operateshe is made leader in next week’s leadership contest.By Sam McBrideWednesday, th May , : pm  "       "  The Lagan Valley MLA set out his manesto yesterday in a glossy four-page document sent to the  other MLAs and MPs whose votes will decide who replaces Arlene Foster at the helm of the partyMr Poots’ manesto amounts to a devastating critique of how the party has been run over recent years.The Stormont minister said that he was aiming to “restore DUP fortunes and revitalise and rebuild unionism”, which he said “means taking an innovative approach to leadership”.   " fill"#ea"  to our daily newsletterThe i newsletter cut through the noiseThanks for signing up!Sorry, there seem to be some issues. Please try again later.Submitting...He said that he wanted to “restore DUP fortunes and rebuild unionism” and that “the DUP has to win back the trust and support of voters” – an implicit acceptance that both the DUP and unionism are now in a bad place.Mr Poots said that the DUP “must be restructured and re-energised” and that he wanted the party to be capable of “leading ALL of unionism”.Confirming what the Sunday Le reported at the weekend, Mr Poots said: “I will separate the jobs of leader and first minister. One person simply can’t do justice to both demanding jobs. Each job demands % from the office holder.”That decision means that Mr Poots, unlike his predecessors, will not receive a larger salary from the DUP leadership – the first minister’s position attracts a salary of £,.Mr Poots said that he had a plan “that will transform the DUP structures and s”, suggesting that he has been planning this move for some time.He went on: “From top to bottom, we have to drive up transparency. Stimulate greater engagement. Listen to what members say...as leader, I want to put ‘democracy’ back into the Democratic Unionist Party”.Mr Poots, who has not stopped his officials from building and then operating the Irish Sea border, pledged to “lead the campaign against the undemocratic protocol and systemically undermine and strip away all aspects of it”.The DUP veteran said that he would lead an “extensive outreach programme across unionism loyalism” and establish a unionist convention – a longstanding request of the UVF-linked PUP.He also promised a “pro-Union strategic think tank that includes academics, business figures, and civic and political unionism to broaden support for the Union to avoid a border poll”, as well as a “pro-Union foundation which will support projects designed to strengthen the Union” and international outreach “to better explain the unionist cause in Brussels, London and North America”.Some DUP sources backing Mr Poots’ campaign have said that he is planning to remove some of the party’s most powerful backroom figures such as chief executive Timothy Johnston, chief spin doctor John Robinson and Mrs Foster’s chief spad, Emma Little-Pengelly.However, a source within Mr Poots’ campaign yesterday said that it was “far from the case” that there would necessarily be a “clear out” and said that the iniduals named by others “are not targets”.:Sam McBride: How Arlene
